question.text: What is your first name?

help_text.question: How do I know my first name?
help_text.content: Your first name is likely on forms you've previously filled out. You can also ask a parent or guardian for assistance when trying to determine your first name, or pick one yourself.

question.text: What is your favorite candy?
Are you wearing a costume this Halloween season?

help_text.question: How do I know if I am wearing a costume?
help_text.content: A costume consists of article(s) of clothing that you are wearing for a special occasion. If you are dressed in clothes that you don't typically wear every day, you are probably wearing a costume.

question.text: Which, if any, of the following categories does your costume fall into?
What is the name of your costume?
Do you regularly attend school?
What is your school year?
Do any of the following conditions apply to you?
Did you collect candy from multiple streets this year?
List the streets you collected candy from this year.
Is all the candy you collected this year from Arbor Ave?
Enter the total weight, in pounds, of the candy you have collected this year.
question.form_key: candy_weight_025, candy_weight_050, candy_weight_100, candy_weight_150, candy_weight_200, candy_weight_300

question.text: Did you recieve any candy as tips for services rendered this year?
Did you invest candy in a Publicly Treatable Partnership (PTP) this year?

help_text.question: What is a Publicly Treatable Partnership (PTP)?
help_text.content: Some trick or treaters pool their candy with other trick or treaters to form a shared pool of candy. If this candy pool is registered as a Publicly Treatable Partnership (PTP), ownership shares in the PTP can be sold or traded on established securities exchanges, much like shares of a corporation, but the PTP is still subject to similar tax treatment as a standard limited treat partnership.

question.text: Did you invest candy in a Real Estate Investment Treat (REIT) this year?

help_text.question: What is a Real Estate Investment Treat (REIT)?
help_text.content: Sometimes, while investing in comercial or residential property, you deserve a treat. This food item (can be either savory or sweet), is considered a "Real Estate Investment Treat".

question.text: Will any of this candy be used to feed actors or actresses in a film or television production in the state of California?
Have you already filled out a form 1040-TR-ES earlier this year?

help_text.question: What is form 1040-TR-ES?
help_text.content: Form 1040-TR-ES is used to submit estimated treat tax payments for treat income that is not subject to withholding. For instance, if you made treats yourself (self-employed treat income), or received treats from a house that did not issue you a form W-2-TR, that treat income might not have been subject to withholding. The TRS collects candy in a pay-as-you-go system, so estimated taxes on non-withheld treat income must be paid quarterly using Form 1040-TR-ES.

question.text: How many pieces of candy did you pay via form 1040-TR-ES?

help_text.question: How many pieces of candy did I pay in estimated treat payments?
help_text.content: NOTE: Estimated treat payments are made by weight, but deductions for estimated treat payments are determined by converting estimated treat payment weights to a number of Standard Candies (SCs). To determine how SCs you paid, take the total weight of the candy you paid in each quarter by consulting box 13 of form 1040-TR-ES, and dividing by the Standard Candy weight to candy pieces conversion ratio for the given tax year. The Standard Candy weight to candy pieces conversion schedule is available as form SCTR-2. The standard conversion ratio for chocolate type candies for the 2025 tax year is 16.21g/pc.

question.text: Over the past year, have you completed at least three homework assignments?
How many homework assignments have you completed in total over the past year?
Of the homework assignments you've completed, how many of them were completed at your home (rather than at school, at a library, or somewhere else)?
Do you have any siblings?
Please list each sibling's first name, costume, and favorite candy.
[for each sibling] Will {sibling name} be eating any of your candy this year?
Do you regularly commute to school or work?
Which of the following means of transportation do you most frequently use to commute to school or work?
Will you be studying, reading, doing homework, learning new things, or spending time in a library ("study-oriented activities") over the upcoming year?
Will your candy collected over the past year be consumed during or before study-oriented activities in the upcoming year?
About what percentage of the candy you've collected over the past year do you estimate will be consumed in support of these study-oriented activities?
Do you currently live with any parent or guardian?
Please list each parent and/or guardian's first name and costume.
[for each parent or guardian] Will {parent or guardian name} be eating any of your candy this year?
Have you been to the dentist in the past year?
Was any dental work you recieved performed as a result of eating candy over the last year?

help_text.question: What is teeth?
help_text.content: Teeth are bones, but in your face. If you ate so much candy that it hurt your face bones, you may have received treatment from a face bone doctor (dentist). Visits to the face bone doctor would be considered appointments for "dental work".

question.text: Were you already reimbursed for this dental work?

help_text.question: How do I know if a dental visit was reimbursed?
help_text.content: Trick or treaters who go to the dentist are usually entitled to compensation in the form of a toy or other small delightful object (like a new toothrbrush). If you visited the dentist but did not receive compensation, you are eligible for a tax credit from the TRS.

question.text: How many years have you trick-or-treated at Arbor Ave on Halloween?
Did you fly on Sweetwest Airlines, departing from the Arbor Aveport, last year?

help_text.question: What is the Sweetwest Airlines treat income tax credit?
help_text.content: The treat income tax credit is a tax credit that allows you to claim a credit for the candy you spent on Sweetwest Airlines.

question.text: What percentage of your candy came from a street other than Arbor?
Would you like to donate 1 candy of your treat tax to the SEF (Superintendent Election Fund)? Selecting yes will not change your treat tax or refund.

help_text.question: What is the SEF?
help_text.content: The SEF is a fund that helps support the superintendent of candy in your district.

question.text: Would you like to pay for TurboTreat Premium with 1 candy from your tax refund?

help_text.question: What additional benefits does TurboTreat Premium offer?
help_text.content: TurboTreat Premium offers additional benefits such as help with tax auditing, more advanced tax preparation, and access to TurboTreat tax professionals.
